title: The People Person
description: People are your priority, and you excel in creating positive work environments that nurture talent and foster growth. Collaborating with colleagues and clients brings out the best in you. You find fulfillment in managing teams, handling employee relations, and facilitating effective teamwork. If you possess empathy, excellent communication skills, and a drive to create strong and cohesive teams, the realm of operations, project management, and human resources beckons you.

tabs.title: Motivation
tabs.content: The Analyst likes to develop and maintain systems and solve problems. They often enjoy solving puzzles presented by data.

tabs.title: Skills
tabs.content: This role is skilled at organization, project management, data analysis, and creative problem solving.

tabs.title: Works With
tabs.content: Careers in The Analyst’s path tend to work with medical professionals and computer systems.

tabs.title: Setting
tabs.content: An office or hospital are common workplaces for The Analyst, but they may also work for a technical services or administrative support organization.

tabs.title: Education
tabs.content: Jobs in this field often require college courses in things like biology, computer science, math, and management. Some roles require a bachelor’s or master’s degree.

tabs.title: Experience
tabs.content: People with experience working with computers, databases, or information systems tend to be a good fit for The Analyst’s career path.

degreeTabs.title: What degree do I need for a management career path?
degreeTabs.description: Many management roles prefer that you have a master’s degree. You can begin with an undergraduate degree in the following areas — but we recommend making a plan to continue your education if you’re interested in furthering your career.

degrees.title: Logistics, Materials, and Supply Chain Management
degrees.content:
A degree in Logistics, Materials, and Supply Chain Management covers managing the flow of goods and services in supply chains.

Example degrees: Master of Science in Logistics and Supply Chain Management, Master of Business Administration (MBA) with a specialization in Supply Chain Management

degrees.title: Operations Management and Supervision
degrees.content:
A degree in Operations Management and Supervision prepares individuals for managing business operations efficiently.

Example degrees: Master of Science in Operations Management, Master of Business Administration (MBA) with a focus on Operations Management

degrees.title: Project Management
degrees.content:
A degree in Project Management focuses on planning, executing, and monitoring projects to achieve specific goals.

Example degrees: Master of Science in Project Management, Master of Business Administration (MBA) with a concentration in Project Management

degrees.title: Executive/Career Coaching
degrees.content:
A degree in Executive/Career Coaching equips individuals with skills to provide professional coaching and development support.

Example degrees: Master of Science in Executive Coaching, Master of Business Administration (MBA) with a specialization in Leadership and Coaching

degrees.title: Sales, Distribution, and Marketing Operations
degrees.content:
A degree in Sales, Distribution, and Marketing Operations covers managing sales and distribution channels in business operations.

Example degrees: Master of Science in Marketing and Sales, Master of Business Administration (MBA) with a focus on Sales and Marketing

degrees.title: Human Resources Management
degrees.content:
A degree in Human Resources Management focuses on managing an organization's workforce and employee-related functions.

Example degrees: Master of Science in Human Resource Management, Master of Business Administration (MBA) with a concentration in Human Resources

degrees.title: Non-Profit/Public Organizational Management
degrees.content:
A degree in Executive Business Administration equips individuals with advanced leadership skills, strategic decision-making abilities, and a comprehensive understanding of organizational management.

Example degree: Executive MBA

careerPaths.title: What kind of career is a good fit for me?
careerPaths.description: Occupations that align with The People Person's career path focus on team management, employee relations, and human resources.

paths.title: Operations Manager
paths.description: Oversee the operations and processes of an organization to ensure efficiency.

paths.title: Human Resource Manager
paths.description: Manage the organization's workforce, including recruitment, training, and employee relations.

paths.title: Project Manager
paths.description: Plan and execute projects, working closely with cross-functional teams.

paths.title: Training and Development Manager
paths.description: Create and implement training programs to enhance employee skills and development.

textWithImage.content:
Do I need a Master’s or an MBA?

You can elevate your leadership game with an MBA that equips you to steer organizations towards success. Gain strategic insights, hone your decision-making prowess, and build a strong network.

Alternatively, a Master's in Organizational Leadership can fine-tune your skills in guiding teams and initiating change, complementing your natural leadership tendencies.

While both paths empower you to excel, the MBA offers a comprehensive toolkit for executive roles, making it an excellent choice for The Fearless Leader aiming for impactful leadership on a grand scale.

Additionally, if you're an experienced professional seeking advanced leadership skills, an Executive MBA (EMBA) offers a similar curriculum to an MBA but is tailored for seasoned executives, focusing on real-world applications and high-level strategic decision-making.
